channel.title: tidyverse on Pete Talbert
channel.description: Recent content in tidyverse on Pete Talbert

item.title: For loops for quick summaries in R
item.description: Because I often work with categorical data, I find myself making lots of quick, sorted counts of variables in a dataset. I find that this is a really common technique to get to know a dataset you’re working with; I’ve also noticed David Robinson do it often in his screencasts.

item.title: Window Functions in SQL vs. R
item.description: Both MS SQL Server and R’s dplyr package offer window functions for different operations on a dataset. What are window functions? Window functions operate on a set of rows or “window” and return a value for each row, whether that’s something like a row number or percentile rank, or an aggregate result from a min, max, average, or sum.

item.title: Plotting factors with forcats
item.description: Often, I find myself with a lot of categorical variables that I want to plot, where I’m really only interested in the most common ones that bubble to the surface.

item.title: Pivoting Data in SQL vs. R
item.description: Often with education data, I need to pivot data to go from long format to wide. For instance, I often have test scores for different test subjects of a single assessment.

item.title: ggplot2 geom_bar Labeling
item.description: In educational data analysis, I am constantly looking at counts and proportions. I’ve found the easiest way to display these results with categorical variables like demographics is to use stacked bar charts and especially 100% stacked charts.
